newsitem.title: USA: Florida citrus belt warm and dry in early May.
newsitem.headline: Florida citrus belt warm and dry in early May.

text.p: The Florida citrus belt saw a "normal" first week of May, with virually no rainfall, warm to hot temperatures and love bugs throughout the region, the Florida Agricultural Statistics Service (FASS), said.

In its weekly weather and crop update, FASS said there continues to be an abundance of new growth on recently fertilized younger trees in many groves. New crop fruit is making normal progress and the remaining harvest of Valencia oranges are in excellent condition, according to FASS.
Growers have been irrigating to maintain good tree condition and caretakers are mowing, chopping and discing cover crops, FASS said.
FASS reported an estimated 8,028,000 boxes of Valencia oranges were harvested in the week ended May 11, up from 6,950,000 in the prior week and compared with 7,383,000 during the week ended April 27.
